headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Second Provocative Flag Seen Flying Outside Alito Home; Trump Rises Slightly in Nationwide Polls. Aired 6-6:30a ET

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yikes. A strong gust of wind causes a stage to collapse in Mexico. The death poll now rising.And -- (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) NIKKI HALEY (R), FORMER PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I will be voting for Trump. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: She said America wouldn't survive four more years of Trump. Now, Nikki Haley is voting for him.And -- (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TAYLOR SWIFT, SINGER
utterances.sentences: Welcome to the Eras Tour.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: It started with a Taylor Swift ticket debacle. Now, the Justice Department is suing the owner of Ticketmaster.And the Mooch, Anthony Scaramucci, joins us. He wants to be your life coach. Six a.m. here in Washington. Here's a live look at Capitol Hill on this Thursday morning. Good morning, everyone. I'm Kasie Hunt. It's wonderful to be with you. Another provocative, controversial flag seen flying outside a home owned by Supreme Court Justice Samuel Alito. "The New York Times" publishing this photo of the flag outside Alito's New Jersey beach home last summer. The flag, which features a pine tree and the phrase, "Appeal to heaven," dates back to the Revolutionary War. But today, as "The Times" wrote, the flag has become, quote, "a symbol of support for former President Donald J. Trump for a religious strand of the Stop the Steal campaign, and for a push to remake American government in Christian terms." This is video from the January 6 riot. On the right of the screen amid the mob forcing its way into the Capitol to try to prevent the peaceful transfer of power, you see the same pine tree flag flying. Just last week, "The Times" published a photo of an upside-down American flag outside Alito's Virginia home. That is another symbol of the Stop the Steal pro-Trump movement. Justice Alito has not commented publicly on the pine tree flag. He did release a statement last week about the upside-down flag. He claimed his wife flew it after a fight with neighbors. John Bolton, the former Trump national security adviser, talking to my colleague Wolf Blitzer last night about the pine tree flag and saying it's not a big deal. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JOHN BOLTON, FORMER TRUMP NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR
utterances.sentences: I think it is outrageous -- outrageous and unacceptable -- for people to take a flag from the American Revolution and say that, because some January 6 protesters flew it, that it's now unacceptable to fly that flag. And I'd like to hear a Democratic Party politician say that expressly.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right. Our panel is hereElliott. I want to start with you. I want -- we'll get to the politics in a second in terms of why John Bolton wants to see a Democratic politician --

utterances.speaker: ELLIOT WILLIAMS, CNN LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: -- saying this kind of thing.But the issue is -- is that Justice Samuel Alito isn't accountable to anybody. He's a Supreme Court justice who is supposed to be impartial in the face of the law. What are -- to the extent there are rules about this kind of thing, I mean, what is he supposed to be doing? What kind of signal does it send? And -- and do you view this -- I mean, do you view these two things also, I would say as equally problematic. The upside-down American flag and this pine tree flag?

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: I mean, my -- my honest -- my honest question looking at that, if -- can we put those flags back up, the Alito flags, the three of them? Like isn't the American flag supposed to be flying at the top there, flagpole? I mean --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well -- well --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Like, isn't that traditionally what -- where you would put it, right?

utterances.speaker: SCOTT JENNINGS, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: They were flying American flags January 6. I mean, I -- look, the word "reasonably" --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: -- is doing a lot of work here. In my opinion, no reasonable person would conclude that Sam Alito is somehow compromised because he's flying a flag that was commissioned by George Washington himself.Ninety-eight percent of people who were outraged about this today didn't even know it existed --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Sure, sure.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: -- 12 hours ago.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me -- here's another example for you. Imagine another one of the justices -- we'll just say Elena Kagan -- flies a flag right now in the midst of campus protests and all that's going on in the Middle East with a slice of watermelon on it, right?Now, you're looking puzzled, because you're like, well, why does that matter? It's a delicious fruit. It's got lycopene in it. Who cares? It's also a sign of the Palestinian resistance.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Now we might think that -- but Scott --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I think -- I actually think if Alito wanted to be popular with "The New York Times," he would fly that. He'd fly Hezbollah flags. He'd fly Hamas flags.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And -- and -- and --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I mean, this is crazy. It's crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: in any of those instances, if the -- if the court -- look at the rules. If the court has business involving national security or Hezbollah or Palestinian, he [SIC] should recuse from those cases, too.So I think we're in agreement here that --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: No, we're not.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We are. We are, because --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: So you'd be cool with it? You'd be cool with the justice --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I don't care about the landscaping choices of Sam Alito. I don't -- I don't. And I think this is part of a years-long effort to delegitimize this branch of government.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, they did that to themselves.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: And what, to me, the big story is one political party --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: -- has been conditioned to believe that, because Trump was illegitimate, the Supreme Court is illegitimate, because he put three people on it. And everything that flows from it is illegitimate.And there is a concerted campaign to delegitimize all these people. And it has -- it has come now down to critiquing the choices of decor.

utterances.speaker: MARK PRESTON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: It's not just -- it's not --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's not -- OK. Here's another example. I care deeply about the Boy Scouts of America, as you know. I know your boys are Cub Scouts, too. If I carve the Scout fleur-de-lis in my lawn, fine. If I'm a SupremeCourt justice, and the Boy Scouts have litigation in front of me, that is a sign of bias under the Supreme Court's rules. And so it -- you know, we're -- I think we're conflating a bunch of things. It's the left versus the right and what Democrats say about the Supreme Court and what the rules that he signed last year governing his own conduct say. And plainly, that -- it's a political symbol, even if it's that has --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Says who?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Scott, there's people flaying it as a --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Says who? That's the question.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: An upside-down American flag?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm talking about the pine tree flag.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Either of them, though.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Which no one -- which is not a popularly known symbol. But you're ascribing a meaning to it.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: It does have --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Look, by the way, I worked on Alito's confirmation. I'm the only person here that did it. I know him a little.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I -- there is no conceivable way, in my opinion, that he's flying a flag to give anyone a reasonable idea that he is about to tip his hand on a case.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: OK -- OK.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: But it does underscore his position in our political system. He is using that symbol to align himself with other people who fly -- who also present the symbol. And what I think Elliot is saying is that that's not right for a justice to do, regardless.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. I'll keep putting these out there. Scott, a Black Lives Matter flag, the justice flies it over their home. Is that -- and there are racial justice or police brutality issues coming before the court. Is that not a sign of bias or -- I mean -- it's a non-profit organization?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: But that -- but that -- but that flag has been created in -- in the moment to make a political statement.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Kind of like flying flags on January 6th.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: No. The flag -- the flag that you're criticizing was created by George Washington to flow over frigates in the Revolutionary War. You can't see the difference in that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Scott, I --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it's not unbelievable. I'm saying it's -- this is -- these are all --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Unreasonable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All of the examples I gave --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Your old boss went before the Supreme Court and said they would reap the whirlwind if they don't start acting right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All of these --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I understand how you all view it. I just --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Whoa, whoa, whoa. There's no "you all" here.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to view this as a reasonable argument.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes, let's be --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm just literally reading the rules that these folks wrote and giving you examples of things that, like the American Revolutionary flag --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: But you're equating George Washington's flag with the BLM flag?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I'm -- I'm equating flags that have --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: He's giving you different examples.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: But they don't match, is my point.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Also not a political symbol.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It is if they've got -- Scott --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: By the way, they don't even call it the "Boy Scouts" anymore.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's not a question of the political symbol. It's the question of matters that could come before the Supreme Court. They were weighing issues related to that very protest that people were talking about here.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: And they still are. They still are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the justices, necessarily --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: I mean, that's the thing, right? Like, they still are. They have before them this massive question of immunity right now. It all relates to the flying of this.And I mean, why shouldn't -- why does he need to fly it, right? Like, couldn't you look at it that way, like --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I mean this. How about this, right? Why do to fly it? I mean, he -- does this man not live under the same First Amendment as the rest of us?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He does, but he also is on the Supreme Court. A justice of the Supreme court.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: But he's a Supreme Court justice!

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: So?

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: So -- so --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: He's a Supreme Court Justice. Mark, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Let me put in a couple of things in perspective.I actually live near the justice; knew nothing about this flag. OK?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: A year ago. In fact the neighborhood didn't necessarily know about the flag. So somebody clearly --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Are you're talking about the one in Virginia?

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: The one in Virginia, yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: The one -- OK. So this is the upside-down American flag.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Which -- which Scott, by the way, happens to be on George Washington's farm. George Washington used to -- used to own that land there.OK. Here's the issue in Washington, D.C. There are many couples in Washington, D.C., who have conflicted relationships in the sense the husband or the wife works for something, works for somebody where there could be a conflict where their spouse works, OK? So that happens all the time.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: James Carville and Mary Matalin were married to each other. I don't know if that follows it, but anyway.

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Well, right. But -- no, look, the reality is he should -- should he have flown the flag? No, Scott, he shouldn't have flown the flag. Should he be allowed to fly the flag? Like there's nothing stopping him from doing it.But he's a Supreme Court justice. He answers to no one. Why would you want to put the flag up there? I mean, that's it. I agree with you that it's an issue that is blowing up, and -- and it's going to be made of something maybe making something out of nothing, basically. But the reality is, he shouldn't have done it anyway, because this is what is going to happen.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right. I've got to wrap this up, Scott. I just want to just nail down something. You do see a distinction between the upside-down American flag and this George Washington flag?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: You do not?

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I don't personally believe that the flag choices at Alito's House have anything to do with his impartiality or ability to render his duties as a Supreme Court justice.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: And so you're cool with him flying an upside-down American flag? Because I mean, even Lindsay Graham looked at that and said, like, Come on, you're a Supreme Court justice.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: I don't care. And I think his -- and I have no reason to disbelieve his explanation. Everybody seems to think he's lying about his explanation. Do I have -- do I believe that his wife had a dispute with a neighbor? Yes. I think he's an honest person. And if that's what he says happened, I believe him.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. Another 2024 presidential poll revealing the race is too close to call.Former president -- former -- President Biden, and former President Trump separated by a single percentage point -- of course, well within the margin of error -- in this new polling from Quinnipiac University. But one thing we did notice is that it looks different from this Q Poll back in January, which had Biden at 50 and Trump at 44 percent. And you can see that Donald Trump's support does seem to be growing here in this particular survey. Panel is back. Mark Preston, I wanted that graph because I don't like to put too much stock in any single poll. But when you kind of map it out, you can see some of the changes here. We've seen this reporting that President Biden doesn't believe the polls, and that's why they want to just stay the course here. But when you look at this, it just seems to me hard to deny that in the last few months -- And let's remember, you know, this polling did come out as the country's been absorbing the Trump trial. This latest Q Poll is there. What do you make of this? And how concerned do you think the Biden team should be?

utterances.speaker: PRESTON
utterances.sentences: Well, two things. One, I think -- I think that the country is obviously divided and almost evenly divided at this point. And I do wonder if this Manhattan court case has caused exhaustion for voters. And they're looking in. And at some point, Donald Trump coming out every day and -- and talking about how he has been a victim and having the speaker of the House come up and speak on his behalf. I do wonder if that is -- is hurting the Biden campaign a little bit. I really do.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Scott.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: It's a close race. I don't know who's going to win. I don't have a strong feeling.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: None of us do. I -- let's --

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: Some days I wake up feeling one, and some days I wake up feeling the other. I do think thisI mean, I know some Democrat operatives who believe Biden's got to win the national popular vote by a couple or three points in order to be assured of a -- of an Electoral College victory.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: So if I were Biden now, I'd be very worried about that.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes. And again, I mean, to your point, it's the swing states, right, that really matter. The most recent swing-state polling we have, Elliot, looked at. It was from "The New York Times"/Siena poll, and it came out a couple of weeks ago.One thing that I was really interested in in that was actually the disparity between the Biden-Trump number and some of these Senate races. Because the Biden-Trump number was really close. The Senate wasn't. Look at the Pennsylvania numbers. It had Biden up at 44 and Trump at 47. So Biden's trailing, in this poll, Trump. But then look at that. That's Bob Casey and Dave McCormick. Bob Casey, the Democratic incumbent, sitting at 46, right? He's running well ahead of Trump [SIC]. Now let's look at Arizona. Same thing: Biden 42 in Arizona, Trump 49. Ruben Gallego, the Democrat, 45; Kari Lake, 41. The difference almost. That's important is not even, you know, the Gallego versus Lake difference. It's that you're seeing Gallego run ahead of Biden here. Usually -- I mean, oftentimes, the trend -- that's not the trend. The trend can be reversed. Why do you think that is? I mean, "The Times" said it was actually Gen Z and voters of color.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's a big part of it. Also, I was wondering, at least in the Casey race, if name recognition as part of it. And if voters simply are not aware --

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- of who David McCormick is yet.Now, the Arizona numbers throw that off a little bit, because Kari Lake has been a statewide figure for quite some time.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: We saw -- we also saw this in Nevada, too, I will say, and there was another race, as well.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: The Lake vote -- the Lake result, if I were -- that's -- they know her. She's sitting --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: They know her.

utterances.speaker: JENNINGS
utterances.sentences: They know her, and she's sitting that low. I mean, I think you're right on some of the other races that name I.D. could be an issue. Campaigns haven't really started yet. But for Lake that was pretty troubling for her.

utterances.speaker: HUNT
utterances.sentences: All right, 25 minutes past the hour. Five things you have to see this morning.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) (CRASHING NOISES) (END VIDEO CLIP) Yikes. A Mexican presidential candidate briefly hospitalized after a deadly stage collapse at a campaign event. Nine people were killed and at least 15 others injured when a powerful wind gust brought the stage down. A tornado touched down just South of Waco, Texas, causing widespread damage and leaving roads impassable. This video, taken outside a shopping mall, shows the aftermath. No fatalities were reported. Stunning video of a Russian drone dropping explosives on a police car that was on its way to evacuate civilians in Ukraine's Kharkiv region. Ukraine has been evacuating civilians from the border areas since Russia launched an offensive two weeks ago. And -- (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) (GLASS BREAKING) (END VIDEO CLIP)
